awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Software and Services to Enable Metabolic Flux Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Metabolic flux analysis (MFA) allows for the determination of biochemical reaction rates inside of living cells, which are otherwise impossible to measure directly. Similar to how Google Maps reports traffic flows within highway networks, MFA can identify cellular pathway bottlenecks (roadblocks) and wasteful metabolic processes (detours) within biochemical networks. This information can be used to engineer improved production systems (e.g., host organisms and/or cultivation platforms) for use in industrial bioprocesses or agriculture. The MFA technology can also be used in biomedical research to identify potential therapeutic targets or diagnostic biomarkers for metabolic diseases. However, most companies do not have the necessary expertise to assess their measurements using MFA due to the sophisticated computational algorithms and data analysis required. At its simplest, the proposed project seeks to broaden the use of advanced metabolic engineering software and techniques developed in the PI?s laboratory for applications in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries.

Metabolic flux analysis (MFA) is a complex analysis technique that encompasses molecular biology, chemistry, biochemistry, cell biology, plant physiology, mathematics, computer science, and engineering. The proposed approach to MFA will be rigorous because this team aims to capture as much information as possible from the available measurements that companies can obtain from their experimental system. Because of this, the immediate impacts within an organization will be an increase in the quality of the science performed. This I-Corps team aims to lead by example by creating testable hypotheses, validating its assumptions, accounting for all sources of error, and analyzing data with attention to detail. MFA, coupled with the proposed approach, has the potential to change for the better how companies perform metabolic engineering. Improved methodologies to assess cellular metabolism have the potential to drive tremendous advances in not just manufacturing efficiency, which is useful for everything from biofuels production to food production, but also for drug discovery and therapeutic applications in metabolic diseases such as cancer or diabetes.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The major goals of the project were to foster entrepreneurship and to evaluate the feasibility of transitioning previously NSF-funded research and technology from the academic lab to the commercial space. Specifically, the INCA team’s goals were to investigate the potential of broadening the use of advanced metabolic engineering software (INCA) and techniques developed in the PI’s laboratory for commercial applications in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. The INCA team completed the I-Corps curriculum by attending both the kickoff and lessons-learned workshops in Reston, VA, while also participating in five online classes. During each class session, the team presented a 10-minute weekly progress report to the teaching team and cohort peers. The team also “got out of the building” and conducted 106 customer discovery interviews during the six-week curriculum. The Entrepreneurial Lead (EL) of the team travelled to San Francisco and San Diego, CA, Raleigh, NC, and Boston, MA to conduct in-person customer discovery interviews. Of the 106 customer discovery interviews performed, 75 were in-person, 4 were via video chat, and 27 were via phone call. The business model canvas was revised each week based on the material discussed during each class session and information gained from customer discovery interviews. Based on the results of the I-Corps project, the INCA team reached a "go" decision to form a company based on the INCA technology and services. This company, Metalytics LLC, was cofounded by the EL and PI. Metalytics is currently working with early adopters identified during the customer discovery process to launch several pilot projects. The company also submitted SBIR proposals to NSF and NIH, which are currently pending.

 

Broader Impacts

The I-Corps curriculum provided a unique learning opportunity, especially for the EL and PI of the team, to gain more knowledge about transitioning technology out of the academic research lab setting and into the commercial space. This has proven extremely useful as the EL and PI move forward with their startup company, Metalytics.  Both a lessons-learned video and a technical video were produced to document the team’s experience with the I-Corps program. Both of these videos can be found via the following links: Lessons Learned video (https://youtu.be/m48eSmRGTN8) and Technical vidco (https://youtu.be/9izOOcdTObI). Based on the findings of the I-Corps customer interviews, Metalytics secured a license agreement with Vanderbilt University for the commercial use of the INCA software. Because of the conversations that took place during the customer discovery process, some I-Corps contacts have also licensed the INCA software from Vanderbilt for their own internal use. The INCA team expects that the use of the metabolic flux analysis software and technology-enabled services will have a widespread impact on the US economy through enabling faster product and process development in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2016
Modified by: Jamey D Young
